mut_sentence: Peculiar to the English is the art of change-ringing, and, like most of their peculiarities, it remains unintelligible to the rest of the world.
`` The Nine Tailors `` by Dorothy L. Sayers
England -- ASLACTON
Amid the fields stands one of the loveliest scenes that evoke rural England: an ancient stone church, its tower cascading the sound of bells, calling the faithful to evensong.
At the church door, the parishioners of St. Michael and All Angels always stop to chat, as is the habit of the members here.
In the tower, the same five bells that first sounded here in 1614 are pulled on rhythmically by five men and women with ropes attached.
A discordant, modern note there is also in Aslacton, though it cannot be heard by the church-goers as they enjoy the peal of bells on this cool autumn evening.
St. Michael, like most of the other 6,000 churches in Britain, once had its own `` band `` of ringers who heralded every Sunday morning and evening service with their sets of bells.
Now, only 64-year-old Derek Hammond remains, the one local ringer.
Elsewhere is where the others live, who are here today.

A group of 15 ringers, including two octogenarians and four in training youngsters, drives every Sunday from church to church in a sometimes-exhausting effort to keep the bells of many belfries in East Anglia sounding.
Even to ring for one service at this tower, scraping is necessary, says Mr. Hammond, a retired water-authority worker.
The youngsters, despite our efforts to train them, have their discos and dances and just drift away.
Mr. Hammond fears that the East Anglian group, which keeps the Aslacton bells pealing, will see its ranks diminished by old age and the flightiness of youth.
After all, history is not on his side.
Why the ancient art is on the ropes is easy to see.
Considered by the English to be childish and fit only for foreigners, the less complicated version of playing tunes on bells is, as do the carillons of continental Europe, not favored.
An exercise the English invented 380 years ago, mind-boggling change-ringing, requires intense mental concentration combined with physical dexterity -- some bells weigh more than a ton.
In `` rounds, `` the highest-pitched bell to the lowest starts off proper English bells -- a simple descending scale using, in larger churches, as many as 12 bells.
At a signal, the order in which the bells sound begins to be varied by the ringers, yet the steady rhythm of the striking remains unaltered.
The rules state that each variation, or change, can occur only once.
Patterns of changes, known as `` methods, `` are memorized by Ringers, which include those with odd-sounding names such as Kent Treble Bob Major or Grandsire Caters.
A `` peal `` is a series of about 5,000 changes and takes three hours approximately.
An idea of the work involved is given by a look at a Thursday night practice at St. Mary Abbot church in the Kensington district of London.
In a circle stand ten shirt-sleeved ringers, each with one foot ahead in a prize-fighter's stance, pulling a rope that vanishes through a small hole in the high ceiling of the ringing chamber.
No one speaks, and it seems as if the snaking of the ropes makes as much sound as the bells themselves, muffled by the ceiling.
Straight ahead the ringers stare, totally absorbed, using what they call 'rope-sight' to watch the other ropes and thus time their pulls.
Far above in the belfry, the huge bronze bells, mounted on wheels, are swung madly through a full 360 degrees, beginning and concluding, surprisingly, in the inverted, or mouth-up position.
To advance or retard the next swing, skilled ringers use their wrists, so that one bell can swap places with another in the following change.

Dorothy L. Sayers, a well-known English novelist, described in a detective-story involving church bells, ringing as `` a passion that in mathematical completeness and mechanical perfection finds its satisfaction. ``
`` Filled with the solemn intoxication that comes of intricate ritual faultlessly performed, `` she added, `` are Ringers.``
Stephanie Pattenden, master of the band at St. Mary Abbot and one of England's best female ringers, admits that ringing does become a bit of an obsession.
A passion usually stays in the tower, however, it does.
More often than not, the church is considered by ringers as something stuck at the bottom of the belfry.
When completed are their changes, and after a sweat they have worked up, often ringers skip off to the local pub, leaving worship for others below.
Some clerics do not find this sitting well.
Equally strong-willed and often non-religious ringers are being pressed by strong-willed vicars to attend services, with the membership of the Church of England steadily dwindling.

The entire band was sacked by the Rev. Jeremy Hummerstone, vicar of Great Torrington, Devon, two years ago because he got so fed up with ringers who didn't attend service; promptly, the ringers set up a picket line in protest.
The tower was sort of a separate premises, treated by them as a self-perpetuating club, says the Vicar Hummerstone.
Today, an entirely new band rings at Great Torrington, of whom several are members of the congregation.
But there are still not enough ringers to ring more than six of the eight bells.
Following a dust-up over church attendance, the bells at St. Mary's Church in Ilminster, Somerset, have fallen silent.
So crunch, crunch, crunch, bang, bang, bang -- from above come the ringers, making a very obvious exit as the congregation is at prayer, he says.
Mixed feelings are admitted by Vicar Marshall regarding this issue, since he is both a vicar and an active bell-ringer himself.
A net to draw people into the church is the sound of bells, he says.
In hopes that the ringers themselves will be drawn into that fuller life, I live.
John C. Baldwin, president, says that the Central Council of Church Bell Ringers, a sort of parliament among ringing groups, aims to improve relations with vicars.
It plans to address students at theological colleges about the joys of bell ringing and will soon release a booklet for every vicar throughout the country, titled "The Bells in Your Care."
Also, the greater problem Mr. Baldwin is attacking is the lack of ringers.
Of the 100,000 trained bellringers in England today, only 40,000 still ring, says one survey.
Also, where the bells need to be rung, ringers do not always live -- such as in small, rural parishes and inner-city churches.
But Mr. Baldwin says that the council's program to attract and train ringers is only partly successful.
After five years, we're lucky if we keep one new ringer out of 10, he adds.
That a growing number of women have entered the once male-dominated field is one bright sign; more than a third of the ringers today are women.
However, they are not accepted everywhere.

Male-only remains the Ancient Society of College Youths, the oldest bell-ringing group in the country, founded in 1637, a fact that's particularly galling to women since it is the sole group providing ringers for the most prestigious churches in Britain, including St. Paul's Cathedral and Westminster Abbey.

This being Britain, an equal-opportunity suit has not been filed by any woman, yet the problem's extent surfaced this summer through a series of letters in the weekly newspaper `` The Ringing World, `` read by ringers.

`` Red-blooded, balanced male, `` one writer signed his letter, remarking on the `` frequency of women fainting in peals `` and suggesting they `` settle back into their traditional role of making tea at meetings.``
One or two men have I seen die, bless them.
A handful of genes, if damaged, can unleash the chaotic growth of cells that characterizes cancer, a process medical scientists are starting to uncover.
The discovery of these genes in recent months, say scientists, is painting a new and startling picture of how cancer develops.
An array of new strategies for future cancer treatment and prevention is expected to be produced by an emerging understanding of the genes.
For the future, that is.
For the first time, tests are being developed by scientists based on the newly identified genes, which can predict whether an otherwise healthy individual is likely to get cancer, already.
A super-exciting set of discoveries, says Bert Vogelstein, a researcher from Johns Hopkins University who has just discovered a pivotal gene for triggering colon cancer.
A decade ago, cancer was a black box at the molecular level about which we knew nothing.
Today, we know that several of these altered genes can initiate a cancer and, subsequently, be the driving force propelling it into a deadly state.
The new class of genes, scientists call them tumor-suppressors, or simply anti-cancer genes.
When a cell's growth is held in check, it is due to proteins that they normally make when functioning.

But if damaged are the genes -- perhaps by radiation, a chemical, or in cell division by a chance accident -- their growth-suppressing proteins no longer function, and cells that are normally controlled turn malignant.
A family of genes discovered in the early 1980s and called oncogenes differs from the newly identified genes.
For a cell to become malignant, oncogenes must be present, but researchers have found them in both normal and cancerous cells, suggesting that cancer is not caused by oncogenes alone.

In recent months, researchers have come to believe that an oncogene may turn proliferating cells malignant only after the tumor-suppressor gene has been damaged, in concert with the two types of cancer genes.
Tumor-suppressor genes, like all genes, inherit in two copies, one from each parent.
For cancer to arise, both copies must be impaired, since either copy can make the proteins needed to control cell growth.

Especially prone to cancer is a person who is born with one defective copy of a suppressor gene, or one copy of which is damaged early in life, because losing only the other copy can lead to the development of cancer.
What some scientists believe to be a new age of predictive cancer diagnosis is being ushered in by emerging genetic tests that will be able to spot such cancer-susceptible individuals.
Among the first beneficiaries of the new findings are Bill and Bonnie Quinlan.

Even before Bonnie became pregnant in 1987, the Dedham, Mass. couple knew that any child of theirs had a 50% chance of being at risk for retinoblastoma, an eye cancer that occurs about once in 20,000 births.
A damaged gene, Mr. Quinlan knew he carried, having lost an eye to the rare tumor at only two months old, a fate that his mother had also suffered when she was a baby.
Last January, it became possible to find out what threat the Quinlan baby faced because of the isolation of the retinoblastoma tumor-suppressor gene.

A test using new `` genetic probes `` showed that no more risk was faced by little Will Quinlan than by other children of developing the rare cancer, as he had not inherited a damaged retinoblastoma supressor gene.
Mr. Quinlan says, `` It made our New Year.``
Whether an individual could expect to develop cancer was reliably predicted by this first test.

The initial discovery of the gene that controls retinal cell growth, equally important, was made by a Boston doctor named Thaddeus Dryja, opening a field of cancer study which has exploded in recent months.
Some fundamental insights about the most basic workings of cancer were made possible by studying a tragic but uncommon tumor, says Samuel Broder, director of the National Cancer Institute.
It may not be obvious to the public that all this is concerned with advances in treatment, but I am convinced that soon this basic research will begin to show results there.
To date, two of these cancer-suppressors have been fingered by scientists.
The retinoblastoma discovery was made by Dr. Dryja in 1986.
Then last spring, a gene called p53, if impaired, was reported by researchers to turn healthy colon cells cancerous.
Evidence that the same damaged p53 gene is present in tissue from lung and breast cancers was uncovered by two other research teams soon after that report.
The most common and lethal forms of the disease are colon, lung, and breast cancers, almost killing collectively 200,000 Americans a year.
About a dozen laboratories in the U.S., Canada, and Britain are currently racing to uncover other suspected tumor-suppressing genes.
About seven candidates they have.

The development of such scourges as cancer of the brain, skin, kidney, prostate, and cervix appears to crucially involve the inactivation of tumor-suppressor genes, whether alone or in combination, researchers say.

There is evidence that these genes, when inherited in defective versions by people, especially predispose them to cancer, which perhaps finally explains why certain families seem to be haunted by some cancers.

The proposal that retinoblastoma stemmed from two separate genetic defects goes back to the 1970s, when made by a pediatrician named Alfred G. Knudson Jr., who was exploring the story of tumor-suppressor genes.
He theorized that in eye cancer, an infant inherits a damaged copy of a gene from one parent and a normal one from the other.
He suggested the tumor developed when also the second, normal copy was damaged.
Dr. Knudson's `` two-hit `` theory could not be proven, no way existed.
Back then, specific genes could not be ferreted out by scientists, but the 23 pairs of chromosomes within the cells containing them could be seen under a microscope.
Gross chromosome damage was occasionally visible.
Dr. Knudson's discovery was that a damaged copy of chromosome No. 13, inherited from a parent affected by the disease, was present in some children with eye cancer.
That a bit of chromosome 13 was missing, he could actually see under a microscope.
The missing piece, he assumed, contained a gene or genes whose loss played a critical role in triggering the cancer.
But which gene or genes had disappeared, he did not know.
The answer was found by a scientific team led by the molecular geneticist Webster Cavenee, then at the University of Utah.
A battery of the newly developed `` gene probes `` was used by the team, snippets of genetic material that can track a gene's presence in a cell.
They found defects in the second copy of chromosome 13, in the exact area as the first copy, by analyzing cells extracted from eye tumors.
That the loss of both copies of the same gene could lead to the eruption of a cancer was shown for the first time by anyone.
Dr. Knudson, now at Fox Chase Cancer Research Center in Philadelphia, says, `` It was extraordinarily satisfying.``
What was true of retinoblastoma, I was convinced, would be true for all cancers.
An audacious claim it was.

Dr. Vogelstein, a young molecular biologist at Johns Hopkins Medical School, believed Dr. Knudson to be right, and set out to repeat the Cavenee experiment with cells from other cancers, but in Baltimore.
One of two research teams in 1984, his reported dual chromosome losses in a rare childhood cancer of the kidney known as Wilm's tumor.
Colon cancer, the second biggest cancer killer in the U.S. after lung cancer, next turned Dr. Vogelstein's attention.
It seems that colon cancer often develops in stages, believed to also arise from multiple `` hits `` on cancer suppressor genes, he thought.

The development of polyps in the bowel often precedes it, with some cases showing an increasingly malignant progression in identifiable stages -- transitioning from less severe to fatal -- as if a cascade of genetic damage were occurring.
Months of tedious and often frustrating probing of the chromosomes began for Dr. Vogelstein and a doctoral student, Eric Fearon, searching for signs of genetic damage.
A confusing variety of genetic deletions began to be uncovered by them, with some existing only in benign polyps, others in malignant cells, and many in both types of polyps and cells.
A coherent picture of cancer development gradually emerged.
Benign polyps would develop if both copies of a certain gene were knocked out.
If the second gene's both copies were deleted then, the polyps would progress to malignancy.
It was clear that for colon cancer to develop, more than one gene had to be damaged.
Other molecular biologists were galvanized by their report.

Ray White at Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Salt Lake City says, `` It was the confirming evidence we all needed to show that critical gene losses contribute to the development of a common tumor. ``
Yet to be nailed by Dr. Vogelstein was the identity of the gene that, when damaged, could flip a colon cell into full-blown malignancy.
Chromosome 17 was the focus of their study.
A gene would probably be constituted by such a piece of DNA.
Dr. Vogelstein was dubious that the search was over when they found it last winter.

The fact that several years earlier a Princeton University researcher, Arnold Levine, had found in experiments with mice that a gene called p53 could transform normal cells into cancerous ones was the source of his doubts.
In exactly the same spot as p53, Dr. Vogelstein found the deletion.
But Mr. Levine had said that cancer was caused by the p53 gene, which promotes growth, whereas the scientists at Johns Hopkins were searching for a gene that suppresses growth.

When the gene found in human cancer cells by the Johns Hopkins scientists was compared with Mr. Levine's p53 gene, they discovered the two to be identical; it was revealed that in his cancer studies, Mr. Levine had unknowingly been observing a damaged form of p53 -- a gene that suppresses cancer.
An obscure gene is suddenly put right in the cockpit of cancer formation by the discovery, says Robert Weinberg, a leading cancer-gene researcher at Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass.
The p53 suppressor gene is now emerging as evidence of involvement in other cancers, too.
In 23 of 38 breast tumors, researchers in Edinburgh, Scotland, found that one copy of chromosome 17 was mutated at the spot where gene p53 lies.
The scientists say that when inherited in a damaged form, the gene may predispose women to breast cancer, often striking multiple members of certain families.
Lung cancer has just been implicated with the p53 gene.
As yet unpublished, there are also reports from several labs of missing p53 genes in tissue taken from cancers of the kidney, brain, and skin.
At the same time, other tumor-suppressor genes are being rushed to be pinpointed by the Johns Hopkins team and others.
Dr. Vogelstein hopes to soon isolate one on chromosome 18, which is also involved in colon cancer.
Another gene involved with some types of colon cancer, thought to be on chromosome 5, is close to being found by Ray White in Utah and Walter Bodmer, a researcher in Great Britain.
Dr. Minna believes that especially lung cancer is prone to those who inherit a defective gene somewhere on one of their two copies of chromosome 3.
The retinoblastoma suppressor gene, recently reported by him and others, may also be involved not only in some lung cancers but in several other more common cancers as well.
Scientists can only speculate where these discoveries will lead.

Gene hunters are collaborating with two major pharmaceutical companies, the Squibb unit of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., to turn the anticipated cascade of discoveries into predictive tests and, maybe, new therapies already.
New cancer drugs to slow or reverse tumor growth, say some researchers, may be based on the suppressor proteins normally produced by the genes.
The growth-controlling proteins made by healthy versions of the damaged genes would be administered to patients, according to the idea.
It may even be possible for healthy versions to replace defective genes, though no one has come close to achieving that so far.
One of the most important steps in the genesis of cancer, Dr. Minna of the National Cancer Institute says, is what we're witnessing the discovery of.
Why can our children not be taught to read, write, and reckon?
It's not that how to we do not know, because we do.
That we do not want is it.

That we do not want to is due to the reason that to achieve effective education, we would need to surrender some cherished metaphysical beliefs about human nature, both in general and specifically regarding young people, as well as to challenge certain cherished vested interests.
It seems almost blasphemous to challenge these beliefs that so dominate our educational establishment, our media, our politicians, and even our parents.
An example is here.
If a sample of American parents were asked, `` Do you wish for the elementary schools to encourage creativity in your children? `` the near-unanimous answer would be, `` Yes, of course. ``
What do we specifically mean by `` creativity ``?
No one can be certain.
In practice, a `` self-expression `` that is equated with encouraging the youngsters' `` self-esteem `` ends up being the result.
A generation of young people is the result, whose good opinion of themselves is only matched by their ignorance and intellectual incompetence.

A romantic rebellion against disciplined instruction, which was (and is) considered `` authoritarian, `` a repression and frustration of the latent talents and the undefined yet wonderful potentialities in the souls of all our children, has been (and is) integral to the whole notion of `` creativity `` in education.
This romantic extravagance is not surprising that parents find so attractive.
Fortunately, their children are wanted by these same parents to receive a decent education as traditionally understood, and they possess enough common sense to recognize what that demands.
Adolescent illiteracy cannot withstand their commitment to `` creativity ``.
The degree to which we -- all of us -- allow this common sense to prevail over the illusions that we also share will determine the future of American education.
Every inch of the way, the education establishment will fight against common sense.
One simple reason ought not to be underestimated, although the reasons are complex.
Far more interesting and agreeable to teachers than is disciplined instruction is what was once called Progressive education.
It is nice for teachers to consider themselves as engaging in `` personality development `` and even nicer to minimize the often disappointing results of those irksome tests.
A superior self-definition as a `` profession `` is also provided to teachers, since they will have passed courses in educational psychology and educational philosophy.
Such courses in college did I myself take, thinking I might end up a schoolteacher.
`` Pap `` courses could all fairly be described as them.
It is unfair, however, to dump on teachers, as opposed to the educational establishment.
Many schoolteachers, I know, are seriously committed, on the whole, to conscientious teaching.
Very few such people, by definition, may be among the 'best and brightest' of their generation.
Doing their jobs well, they need not be otherwise.
Yes, one or two truly inspiring teachers can we all remember from our school days.
But at the hands of those others, our education proceeded, who were merely competent and conscientious.
In this sense, one's family doctor can be compared to a teacher.
He probably would not be a family doctor in the first place if he were brilliant.
If he serves us well, it is because he is competent and conscientious.
Our educational crisis does not involve our teachers as an important factor.
A problem of equity is whether they are or are not underpaid; it is not an educational problem.
To think our teachers would educate our children better if only they got a few thousand dollars a year more is silly libel.
The kind of libel the teachers' unions do not mind spreading is for their own narrow purposes.
The kind of libel that is also found useful by politicians helps them strike a friendly posture on behalf of an important constituency, since it is.
But no evidence exists that, when other things are equal, salary differentials cause educational differentials.
You can be sure that if there were such evidence, you would have heard of it.
To be serious about American education, we wish to know exactly what to do -- and, just as important, what not to do.
Scattered throughout this nation are many successful schools, some of which are in the poorest of ghettos, and they all send us the same message.
We know beforehand which efforts at educational reform are doomed, conversely, in the majority of unsuccessful schools.
If only we could assimilate this knowledge into our thinking, we really do know all we need to know.
In this respect, it would be more helpful if our political leaders were silent, rather than eloquently expressing `` concern. ``
Inevitably, they are inclined to echo the conventional pap, since the least controversial option open to them is this.

At the recent governors' conference on education, it was announced by Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas that `` a comprehensive child-development policy for children under five is needed by this country. ``
A more pressing need would seem to be a comprehensive development policy for governors over 30.
In effect, Gov. Clinton is advocating the extension of the educational system down to the pre-kindergarten years.
This is a child-care program, whether desirable or not, not an educational program.
That very early exposure to schooling improves performance in the first grade is known, but afterward, the difference is quickly washed away.
Let us sum up what we know about education and about those reforms of education that work and those that do not: -- a bad idea is `` Parental involvement ``.
Schools are too often blamed by parents for the educational limitations of their children.
At home, parents should be involved with their children's education, not in school.
It should be seen to by them that their kids do not play truant; they should ensure that enough time is spent by the children on homework; they should scrutinize the report card.
If a school is not meeting the expectations of parents, the option of switching to another should be available to them.
An even worse idea is community involvement.
Decisive is the experience of New York City here.
The prey of ambitious, generally corrupt, and invariably demagogic local politicians or would-be politicians become locally elected school boards, especially in our larger cities.

A 20-year-old commitment to this system of school governance is being disengaged from by New York, even as Chicago and other cities move to institute it, with the city currently in the process of trying to do so.
In our current circumstances, it is probable that increasing education expenditures in most states will worsen things, not improve them.
The simple reason is this: in the classroom, where money's influence is minimal, education takes place.
Unequivocally, even smaller classes have zero effect on the academic performance of the pupils, as decades of educational research inform us -- though they may sometimes be desired for other reasons.
Into the already top-heavy administrative structure flows the new money, which keeps itself busy by piling more and more paper work on the teachers.

In the fact that educational performance has declined, there is neither mystery nor paradox as educational expenditures have increased sharply in real terms over the past quarter-of-a-century -- now spending more per pupil than any other country in the world.
The system works that way.
As their academic potential allows, students should move up the educational ladder.
No student should be graduated from elementary school and permitted to do so without having mastered the 3 R 's at the level that prevailed 20 years ago.

The main purpose of `` tracking `` is less to ensure that the less gifted get the necessary grounding for further study or for entering the modern world of work ( though that is clearly desirable ) than to permit the gifted youngsters to flourish.
That tracking is somehow `` undemocratic `` is a notion that is absurd.
To encourage young men and women to realize their full academic potential is the purpose of education.
That we all have an equal academic potential is not actually believed by anyone in his right mind.
It is generally considered more desirable to use older textbooks -- many of which, alas, are out of print -- than to opt for newer ones.
Modish, trendy, and often downright silly, the latter are at best insubstantial.
Dubious psychological and sociological theories are what they are based on, rather than educational experience.

The influence of the `` New Math `` on American textbooks and teaching methods is one of the reasons why American students perform so poorly in math tests as compared with students from Britain, France, Germany, or Japan.

Just how bizarre this situation is -- with students unable to add or subtract yet `` learning `` the conceptual basis of mathematical theory -- should be appreciated by anyone who reads the article by Caleb Nelson, a recent math major at Harvard, in the November issue of the American Spectator.
Principals with a large measure of authority over the faculty, the curriculum, and all matters of student discipline should, most importantly, head schools.
The best schools, according to the most recent study from the Brookings Institution, are those governed by a powerful head and free of outside interference.
An unambiguous accountability, of course, goes with that authority.
Students with higher morale and superior academic performance are produced by schools structured in this way.
This is a fact -- though it is not surprising, given all the feathers ruffled by it, that one hears so little about it.

Through bleary, tear-filled eyes, Haney peered doubtfully at his drinking companion.
No ready answer had he, as much from surprise as from the fit of coughing.
Drunk or crazy or both, was the man?
But his new-found buddy, he had matched drink for drink until he lost count, and still the man's eyes were clear.
Haney thought to himself that the guy was off his rocker, and he looked away from those eyes.
A strange intensity burned behind them, bright and clear were the eyes, a sort of cold fire illuminating their gaze.
Why did he not notice it before?
How he got tied up with this stranger, he wondered.
But, of course, now he remembered.
After two hours of steady drinking, it was blurred, but the occasion of it came back to him.
As a huge moving van roared through the intersection, the stranger, his head seemingly sunk in thought, began to cross the street against the light.
A horn blared furiously and brakes howled, but the man would have been hit if Phil had not called out to him a second before.
Something anybody might have done without thinking, on the spur of the moment, his shout had been involuntary.
As a matter of fact, if the guy had been hit, he would n't have cared at all.
Actually, when the truck came to a stop, and the angry driver jumped down from the cab and walked back toward them, he regretted opening his mouth.
By then, Haney was being thanked profusely by the stranger, who had one arm around his shoulders as if Haney were an old friend.
As if they had been in a plot together to ruin his safe-driving record, the driver started to curse at both of them.
Then the truck driver's face was looked squarely into by the man he saved, without a word being said.
Very suddenly, the swearing at them was stopped by the driver, who turned on his heel and went back to his truck.
It hadn't occurred to Haney to give it much thought at the time.
Now it was very clearly recalled by him, and he wondered what in those eyes the truck driver had seen to make him back off.
The sort of look it must have been can call a bluff without a word being said.
When their way was lit, they continued across the street.
When the stranger found out that Phil was on the way to one of his favorite bars, he insisted that he buy drinks for both of them.
Alone, Phil usually went and kept to himself, sitting in a corner and nursing his favorite grudges while passing the time.
But he decided that company would not be minded in exchange for free drinks, even though at his job he made good money.
That was like Phil.
If it was worth it, he now wondered, having a screwball for company.
The offer was not taken seriously by him, yet he began to feel uneasy.
When he finally controlled the coughing, Pete -LRB- who had only given his first name -RRB- was still waiting for an answer, he realized; he didn't even seem to wink as he continued to stare.
A weak laugh was managed by Haney.
Guess no one comes to mind, Pete.
Anyhow, thanks
Between the man's eyebrows appeared a faint crease.
You aren't taking me seriously, I think, Phil.
It was meant by me.
Some kind of grudge has everybody.
If it wasn't for you, I might have been hit by that truck.
Returning favors, I believe in.
Anything, I'll do for somebody I like.
Not a cent will it cost you, Phil.
Try me `` ! ! ``, go ahead
Wearily, Phil rubbed his forehead.
Woolly was beginning to be felt by him.
Maybe it would be better to humor the guy, then make an exit.
He really did n't expect anything to come of it, and of it a few people were present
All right, he conceded finally, if you must know, the landlord and I do not get along.
Because I like to listen to the radio and sing, he keeps riding me while I'm taking a bath.
The neighbors complain, he says, but I don't believe it.
Why do they not tell me themselves if it bothers them?
With his eyes closed, the man nodded.
Almost contented he seemed when he looked up again.
No problem.
Your address, give it to me.
A little time will be taken.
Your landlord's habits and movements I want to study first.
It always looks like an accident, I make sure.
If it looks reasonable, maybe suicide.
In that way, the customer faces no trouble.
Up flew Haney's eyebrows.
Modestly, Pete smiled.
He said, 'It's my line of work.'
Before Haney could make his break, five minutes later, the stranger stood up and nodded farewell.
The small but wiry man was watched by Haney as he slipped out the door quickly and silently, and Haney felt relieved that it seemed nobody else noticed his departure.
It seemed as if the strange little man had never been there, but for the other glass on the table, as Phil decided to stay a little longer and time passed.
Before midnight, he returned to his apartment and went to bed, the whole incident out of mind as he fell asleep, some time passing.
Haney was reminded of where he had been the night before by the hangover the next day, Sunday.
The conversation with the weirdy was reminded by his hangover, and he groaned.
Later in the day, he went for more aspirin and the surly landlord, still alive and scowling as usual, was passed by him -- as if tenants were a burden in his life.
On Monday, he went back to work.
By Wednesday the landlord had not died.
Haney mailed the monthly check for separate maintenance to his wife Lolly on Thursday, and wished the stranger could do something about her, of course.
A police car parked in front of the apartment building was what startled him as he was coming home from work.
Inside the lobby, excited talking was taking place among the people standing around.
As he asked one of his fellow tenants what had happened, his spine crawled with a foreboding premonition.
The landlord died.

Another reminder that, at least at the federal level, political `` ticket splitting `` has been on the rise over the past half century is Tuesday's rout of a GOP congressional hopeful in a Mississippi district that hasn't backed a Democratic presidential candidate since Adlai Stevenson.

In only one presidential election year prior to 1948, more than 20 % of the nation's congressional districts selected a candidate from a different party for the White House than they did for the House of Representatives.
A third is routinely that percentage, and twice it has exceeded 40%.
Republicans are favored more by voters in races for president than in those for Congress, as is known.

A greater percentage of the major-party popular vote for president has been captured by the GOP in every presidential election over the past half century, except for the Goldwater presidential candidacy, than it has of congressional seats or the popular vote for Congress.
Nearly the opposite was the pattern prior to 1932.
The results of recent decades are accounted for by what?
At least a partial explanation for the split personality displayed by Americans in the voting booth may be provided by a simple economic theory.
Three assumptions are relied upon by the theory.

When selecting their political agents, voters can `` buy `` one of two brands -- a Republican brand that believes the minimalist state and private markets, with their virtues, are superior to public action and its vices, and a Democratic brand that advocates for big government and public intervention as a remedy to the excesses that come with pursuing private interest.

Two basic responsibilities are those of Congressional representatives while voting in office -- dealing with national issues, such as casting roll call votes on legislation that imposes costs and/or confers benefits on the population at large, and attending to local issues including constituency service and pork barrel.
Because of their belief in a minimalist state, Republican congressional representatives are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than Democratic members of Congress.
What in economic theory is called a prisoner's dilemma faces voters in races for Congress if these assumptions hold, and they have an incentive, at the margin, to lean Democratic.

If a Republican is put into office, not only will their selected legislator be relatively powerless to prevent other legislators from `` bringing home the bacon `` to their respective constituencies, but they will also acquire less in terms of local benefits.
When it comes to national policy making, each legislator is but one out of 535, after all.
Republican is the lean of a voter's incentive, at the margin, in races for the White House.

A GOP president, although likely more effective at preventing other districts/states and their legislators from bringing home local benefits, may also limit such benefits to the voter's particular district/state.
Consequently, the individual voter's standing will be enhanced by lower taxes.
It appears that this exceedingly simple theory can explain several things.

Why ticket splitting has increased and taken the peculiar pattern that it has over the past half century first: Prior to the election of Franklin Roosevelt as president and the advent of the New Deal, a much smaller role in society was occupied by government, and the prisoner's dilemma problem confronting voters in races for Congress was considerably less severe.

Second, it explains the disdain that voters hold for Congress yet their love for their own congressional representatives: the constituents of any legislator appreciate the specific benefits they gain from the legislator, but do not consider the overall cost that comes with every other legislator's actions on behalf of their respective constituencies.
The theory suggests why legislators who pay too much attention to national policy making relative to local benefit-seeking have lower security in office, thirdly.
Virtually immune to defeat have become first-term members of the House, the most vulnerable incumbents.
The defeat of 13 of the 52 freshman Republicans brought into office in 1980 by the Reagan revolution and running for re-election in 1982 was the one exception to this recent trend.
Because these freshmen, in their role as partisans spreading the Reagan revolution, placed emphasis on national policy making, they were more vulnerable to defeat.
Why the Republican Party may have a difficult time attracting viable candidates for congressional office is indicated by the theory, fourth.
Less may potential candidates be discouraged from running by the congressional salary than by the prospect of defeat at the hands of a Democratic opponent.

To the extent that the congressional prisoner's dilemma game works to the disadvantage of potential Republican candidates and their financial backers, the Republican Party will be hindered in its attempts to field a competitive slate of congressional candidates, as they realize this.
At least a partial reason for why ticket splitting has been particularly pronounced in the South may be provided by the theory, fifth.

To the extent that a disproportionate share of power in Congress has been held by Democratic legislators from the South since 1932 and they have been able to translate such clout into more local benefits for their respective constituencies, an especially strong incentive to keep such Democrats in office has been had by voters in the South.
The theory suggests why, generally, Republicans have fared better in Senate races than in campaigns for the House.

This is precisely the pattern one would expect since, in the lower chamber of Congress, local benefit-seeking matters more and national policy making less, if Republicans are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Democratic counterparts.
Does this theory have any empirical support?
The key assumption that Democratic legislators are more willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Republican colleagues is corroborated by three pieces of evidence.
GOP senators turn back roughly 10% more of their allocated personal staff budgets than do Democrats, according to the findings of economists James Bennett and Thomas DiLorenzo.

To the extent that local benefit-seeking involves the primary duty of personal staff, this indicates that the political philosophy of congressional Republicans leads to less attention being paid to narrow constituent concerns.

To the extent that such votes reflect national policy making and take away from the time a legislator could otherwise devote to local benefit-seeking, if the key assumption is valid, Democrats should have lower attendance rates on roll-call votes than do Republicans, second.
Indeed, this is what the data indicate, especially in the case of the House.
The Republican House attendance rate has not been exceeded by the Democratic House attendance rate since 1959.

As shown in the table, a higher proportion of personal staffs are allocated by Democrats to district offices -- where local benefit-seeking duties matter more than national policy making activities do in Washington offices, finally.

When control of the Senate changed party hands between 1986 and 1987, an examination reveals that the noted personal staffing differences in the table cannot be attributed to the Democrats' disproportionate control over other resources such as committee staff, due to their majority-party status, and moreover, these changes in staffing decisions are not solely a result of the party shift.

The Senate provides additional evidence: When holding constant factors such as incumbency advantages and regional differences, the discrepancy in popular votes between Republican presidential and senatorial candidates in states with a Senate election is shown to be a positive function of the onerous federal tax burden per state — a progressive tax rate that impacts higher-income states more severely.
When the prisoner's dilemma is more severe, voters look upon GOP candidates for president more kindly than Republican candidates for the Senate, put more simply.
The same peculiar pattern appears to be taken in ticket splitting at the state government level as at the federal level.
More typically, state government is split along Republican-governor / Democratic-legislature lines than the reverse situation occurs.

A positive function of the state tax rate is revealed by a cross-state econometric investigation, furthermore, to be the difference between the Republican gubernatorial candidate's share of the major-party vote in a state and the Republican share of the lower state house, holding other factors constant.
At least part of the seemingly irrational behavior that voters display in the voting booth, at both the federal and state government levels, may have an exceedingly rational explanation in sum.

All the attraction of sunrise root-canal work was held by most people for ballooning at the de rigueur hour of 6 a.m.
I promptly signed up, feeling the naggings of a culture imperative.
That it requires zip in the way of athletic prowess, or even a measure of derring-do, is the first thing anybody will tell you about ballooning.
So long as looking down is avoided by you.
Even if you hate heights, you can still balloon, they will also tell you.
Do not look down, I still say.
At least not when ascending are you.
What they won't tell you is to not go aloft in anything you don't want to get wet.
I 'm not referring to the traditional champagne drenching that occurs during the back-on-terra-firma toast.
Landing in a canal is what I'm talking about.
A porous wicker basket is used.
No English is spoken by a pilot.
Began at dawn on a dew-sodden fairway and ended at noon in a soggy field, my maiden voyage and novitiates referred to as virgins to wit.
Almost always at dawn or dusk do balloon flights occur, when the winds are lightest.

Lots of coffee drinking came in between while watching the balloons inflate, and there was much standing around deciding who would fly in which balloon and in what order, no more than four passengers in each basket.
When not my turn in the balloon, its progress was followed by me from the chase car, while I listened to the driver holler into a walkie-talkie.

After 20 or so lovely minutes of drifting above the Vosges came the silver mists rising off the river and the French cows ambling about the fields, following long stretches of this attendant ground activity, watching.
With this kind of bird's-eye view of the world, it's hard not to feel that God's in his heaven, even if your pilote in silly plaid beret kept pointing out how `` belle `` it all was.
Out of their stone houses eventually came little French farmers and their little French farmwives, and they put their hands above their tiny eyes and squinted at us.
It is no wonder.
Straight into their canal were we coming down.
You ca n't steer, see, that's the other rule of thumb about ballooning.
And your pilot neither can.
By heating the balloon's air with a propane burner, you can only go up or down, making the top of your head feel hot and riding the air currents.
The chase car is made necessary by which.
Seldom do most balloonists go higher than 2,000 feet, and most average a leisurely 5-10 miles an hour.
When cruising along at a steady altitude, the balloon gives little sense of motion.
Only when one is ascending -- or in our case, descending a tad trop rapidement -- does one feel, well, as if airborne in a picnic basket.
Hissed my companion, who was the only other English-speaking member of the convention and whose knuckles were white, 'What's he doing?'
`` You bet attention , `` I yelled back while leaping atop the propane tanks , `` alligator loafers I 'm wearing ! ``
Simply laughing, our pilot fired up the burner and with another blast of flame lifted us, oh, a good 12-inches above the water level.
For a few feet, we scuttled along before he plunged us into the drink again.

In a soggy patch of field, we eventually came to rest, where the exquisite pleasure of scrambling out of the basket into the mud was had by us while the French half of our ballooning tag team scrambled in.
My watch was looked at by me.
Half-an-hour aloft, barely.
Back in the chase car, around some more did we drive, got stuck in a ditch, and to get us out of it did we enlist the aid of a local farmer, to pull the trailer hitch and free us from the ditch.

Our balloon, having come to rest on a dirt road, was finally rendezvoused with by us, amidst a group of Epinalers who observed the half-an-hour of non-flight activity that included disassembling our craft and the precision routine of yanking it to the ground, punching the air out, rolling it up, and cramming both it and the basket into the trailer.
The most exercise we'd had all morning was this, followed immediately by our driving to the nearest watering hole.
Returning to the golf course meant this: we watched a few French duffers maul the first tee while sitting under Cinzano umbrellas, me nursing an espresso and my ego.
Barely 30 minutes had I been off the ground after a whole morning of ballooning.
The event's envy-quotient, I figured, was near peerless back in the U.S.A.
As for the ride back to camp, into the chase car clambered our pilot and all the other French-speaking passengers.
Left to ride alfresco in the wicker basket were my American companion and I.
As a blase gendarme was passed by us streaking, I couldn't help but rear up on my soggy loafers and salute.

Plan to reduce emissions is drafted by U.N. group

With the release of a document outlining ambitious greenhouse-gas reductions over the next 40 years on Friday, the U.N.-sponsored climate conference -- characterized so far by unruly posturing and mutual recriminations -- saw renewed focus, particularly as industrialized nations are expected to bear most of the burden in the near term.
As much as it illuminated a path forward, the text highlighted the remaining obstacles, which could provide the basis for a final political deal to regulate greenhouse gases.
An important advance it was seen as in a negotiation that is running out of time, with more than 100 world leaders set to arrive in Copenhagen next week.
The text, forged by a U.N. ad-hoc working group, remains silent on the issue of how much money poor countries would receive from rich ones to address global warming over both the short and long term.

A range of options is provided for key questions by it, including how developed and major emerging economies would reduce their carbon output, and at what upper limit of global temperature rise policymakers would be willing to tolerate.
A lot of flexibility is given to the process, said John Coequyt, senior representative of the Sierra Club in Washington.
A 180-page negotiation text was boiled down to focus on what the U.N.'s top climate official, Yvo de Boer, described as 'the big picture' by Michael Zammit Cutajar, who drafted the six-page document.

A possible deal is outlined, in which by 2020, industrial nations would collectively reduce emissions by 25 to 45 percent from 1990 levels, and during the same period, major developing countries would cut theirs by 15 to 30 percent.
Between 50 and 95 percent of emissions would be cut by the countries together by 2050.

On Friday, the European Union also boosted the talks by pledging to provide $3.6 billion a year for the next three years to help poorer countries adapt to the effects of climate change, ranging from coping with floods and droughts to preventing deforestation.
Still, the same sort of verbal fireworks that have dominated the talks for the past week were featured on Friday.

Language requiring binding cuts of greenhouse-gas emissions for industrialized countries compared with voluntary ones by major emerging economies was rejected by U.S. special climate envoy Todd Stern if they were not funded by the developed world.
That the Obama administration is taking a harder line with China than Bush administration officials did just two years ago was signaled by the move.

A deal without the major developing countries stepping up and taking action is not something the United States is going to do, said Stern, who also complained that the text did not ensure the cuts could be verified by outside observers enough.

An hour after Chinese vice foreign minister He Yafei said America's top climate negotiator was either lacking "common sense" or being "extremely irresponsible" for saying earlier in the week that the United States would not help China financially to cope with global warming, Stern made his comments.
At stake is the future economic trajectory of the world's major powers, causing fault lines to erupt both within the developing world and between the industrial world and emerging economies.

As much as the current battle is about saving individual economies, it is about saving the planet, with China and the United States feuding over their respective obligations while the scientific imperative to take bolder action is ignored by the world's two dozen most influential countries, as poorer nations insist.

It's not surprising that the major powers are fighting over who should bear the costs for curbing greenhouse gases, said Ricardo Ulate, a Costa Rican delegate, even as vulnerable countries have become more aggressive in seeking accountability from the big emitters for their actions.
A new economic hegemony is clearly being developed in this game, said Ulate, who also acts as the climate change adviser for Mexico and Central America at Conservation International.

A legally binding treaty in Copenhagen was indicated to be continued to be pushed for by some of the countries most vulnerable to the impact of climate change, although a political deal at best is what most major participants say the talks will produce.
Early Friday morning, a 24-page draft treaty proposal was produced by the Alliance of Small Island States, which consists of 43 members.

Artur Runge-Metzger, who leads international climate negotiations for the European Commission, stated that political pressure has been exerted on the entire political process by the unified push from small island nations, partly because they are demanding action from emerging economies like China and India.
As delegates focused on the fact that they must resolve most of the outstanding issues before the heads of government arrive to strike a deal, new urgency took on the talks.

Stepping off planes, high-level officials including the Indian environment minister Jairam Ramesh and the Chinese vice minister, raced through the Bella Center's halls to closed-door meetings and news conferences, in order to stake out claims that will be arbitrated over the next week.

A challenge is posed by the sprawling gathering -- where each day 13,000 people flow in and out of the convention center, nightly shows are put on by guitar-playing activists mocking the countries they believe are selling out, and draft proposals are exchanged in person on paper instead of by e-mail.
Nearly all of the key ministers are now here, and as early as Wednesday 60 heads of government will gather in Copenhagen, the intensity only building.
Said Carlos Manuel Rodriguez, vice president for global policy at Conservation International, we're getting into the big leagues.
Coming are the heavyweights.

The second auction, which began on Friday, had been paid for by seven American companies to participate in.
The one who lost was the only one to submit a bid.

Twitter Will Be Pointed to by Cheshire Appeal
Half a dozen of them were typing away in the courtroom rows.
Minute by minute, reports of gruesome testimony were sent out via Twitter by them.
In the end, the defense points out that over 140,000 Twitter messages concerned the trial addressing rape and children bound to their beds in a house that was set on fire.

With the judge's imposition of the death sentence voted for by the jury, the widely followed trial of Steven J. Hayes, convicted of killing three members of a Cheshire, Conn. family, is set to come to an official end on Thursday.
Court filings that sketch out appeals arguments, likely to occupy the courts for years, have already been made by lawyers for Mr. Hayes.

That the intense reporting on the trial, including the extensive use of Twitter by mainstream reporters, created a 'circus atmosphere' and led to such widespread and instant saturation with inflammatory details is one of the most provocative - so much so that the jury was improperly swayed by public passions.
Whether new technology requires new courtroom rules could force appeals judges to grapple with the question, according to the claim.

A real danger exists, as I experienced during this trial, that an individual's fair-trial rights are being affected by the inclusion of new technology in the courtroom, said Thomas J. Ullmann, the chief defense lawyer for Mr. Hayes.

Last week, the claims were tersely rejected in a ruling by Jon C. Blue, the trial judge of State Superior Court, who said the news media were `` carefully controlled `` and that passion did not drive the jury, as there was no evidence to suggest it.
The last word on the issue is not likely to be that.
For decades, questions about a trial's fairness have been raised by the coverage of notorious cases, as recognized by appeals courts.

The conviction of a Cleveland osteopath, Dr. Sam Sheppard, for the murder of his wife was overturned by the United States Supreme Court in a landmark 1966 ruling, with its decision in Sheppard v. Maxwell stating that a 'carnival atmosphere' due to the news media prevailed at the trial.
The television show and the movie `` The Fugitive `` are believed by some to have been inspired by the crime.

It might intrigue appeals courts, some lawyers said, to review Mr. Hayes' conviction half a century later, considering the argument that new rules could be necessary to govern ways of communicating from courtrooms unimagined at the time of Dr. Sheppard's case.

A general reason for concern about the impact of new media in high-profile trials exists, said John J. Donohue III, a Stanford Law School professor who, having studied the Connecticut death penalty, reported it was arbitrarily enforced.
The idea that limiting instant communication from courtrooms might make trials fairer might intrigue some appeals judges, according to Professor Donohue.
Just one of many issues outlined by Mr. Hayes' lawyers, the Twitter issue is likely to delay an execution for years, as it will be argued extensively.

It is also claimed by the defense lawyers, for example, that potential jurors' reactions may have been prejudiced against Mr. Hayes when Judge Blue declined to allow the testing of their reactions by showing grisly crime-scene photographs during jury selection.
The photographs of the victims, Jennifer Hawke-Petit, 48, and her daughters, Hayley, 17, and Michaela, 11, have been said to horrify some of the jurors.

The defense lawyers say they will also challenge the constitutionality of the death penalty, argue that a juror critical of prosecutors was wrongly removed by the judge, and that he added improper pressure for a verdict by deciding unusually to direct the jury to deliberate over a weekend.
The jurors were not kept sequestered.
The most interest may be drawn by their arguments about the effect of the intense coverage of the trial.

In a challenge to the verdict filed last month, they noted that the case, dominating the news in Connecticut, was discussed during the election campaign by candidates for governor and the United States Senate.
The news media continually fanned the flames of emotion about the case, they argued.
The lawyers wrote that the daily crush of media tweets, cameras, and reporters outside the courthouse was anything unlike ever seen here in New Haven, and perhaps even statewide.
The controversial focus is on the Twitter coverage.

A Luddite view that would make poor court policy governing coverage of future trials, some journalists claimed in interviews, is the belief that instant news is more incendiary than reports delivered more slowly.
But arguments that social and technological changes required adaptation by the courts were often attractive to appeals courts, some lawyers said.
That claim is being pressed by Mr. Hayes's lawyers.
Because of the trial coverage, they referred to the Supreme Court's 1966 decision overturning Dr. Sheppard's conviction in their filing, making it clear that new rules were required by the new media.
`` The Sheppard v. Maxwell of the 21st century is represented by this case , `` they wrote.
Fraud law and sport
Such tricks as those of Alonso and Ramos before the Ajax demonstrate wittiness but not the will to remove a sanction.

Presumably forged by two players of Real Madrid, Xabi Alonso and Sergio Ramos, the expulsion in the game played on the 23rd of November against Ajax in the European Champions League has led to rivers of ink being spilled over whether such behavior is unsportsmanlike and if both players should face sanctions from UEFA.
As we all know, a few minutes before the end of the game, which their team had already won, both players deliberately wasted time, causing the referee to issue a second yellow card to each of them.

This way, as Real Madrid will emerge as the leader of its group, the next league game against Auxerre will see both players serving the required sanction, after which they can be free of the cards in the subsequent phase.
Jose Mourinho, the trainer of the team, has been sanctioned with two games by the UEFA committee of discipline, as have the implied players with different economic amounts.
In the world of football, it is not a new practice to see a yellow card provocation in circumstances similar to this one, but rather a frequent occurrence.
So extended is it that it is part of the ethos, of the unwritten rules, yet it is followed by this sport nonetheless.

The fact that the team of the Real Madrid organization, which presumes of nobility and honor in its hymn and has fined its players for analogous acts, has carried out, is a cause of the debate arisen in the related case, further dramatized, apparently, by Mourinho, adding one more incident to his history as a histrionic and provoking technician.

If that type of behavior not specifically prohibited by the regulation contradicts the principles of the sport, as the debate suggests, then it is respectful to the sport's regulation but seems to evade its spirit; that is to say, if these actions constitute fraud.
The type of damage that is brought to the sporting spirit is examined by the matter.
The physical integrity of the opposite players, an aspect that includes the sport spirit as one of its advantages, was not put into danger by these actions, meaning there was no violent game.
It is alluded to another of these advantages with the fare-play, to avoid the team of lawbreaker players taking advantage unjustly of the opposite team, which did not happen either.

However, the paradoxical thing is that the action of the players of Real Madrid did not comply with what we normally characterize as legal fraud, because the rules were violated not secretly to try and avoid the sanction, but most evidently, leading to punishment from the referee.
The sanction was accepted by them without complaints, for which they waited.
What type of advantage the violators obtained in the actions deliberately carried out is another question.

It seems necessary to state here that neither is it a disadvantageous situation for the rival nor is an obtained benefit in the same game, because evidently the action's result supposes their own team with fewer players remaining.
And it is not a useful strategy for the next game either, because those players will not be counted on by the club.
Obviously, the fact that the players will start the next phase of the Championship without cards that could endanger their participation in a future game is the advantage.

But it is about a long-term advantage with a certain degree of indetermination, because the change can eliminate the team first, and in addition, the players fulfill a sanction game with this action, proceeding to the second cycle of cards where the suspension due to card accumulation occurs with one less than in the initial cycle.
So that it is an advantage is not so clear by passing rounds.
Really, those actions are against the sporting spirit, which is part of strategic decisions favoring the advantages allowed by the rules.
The players did not act to avoid the application of the sanction regarding this assumption, but rather chose when to obey it, which would have been a clear case of legal fraud.
A strategic decision was made by them without avoiding the punishment.
Although the border between wittiness and law fraud is diffuse, on this occasion I believe it to be a clear case of wittiness.
The controversy seems to stem from two factors: the manner in which the directive was transmitted and the fact that it led to two auto expulsions.
Not as much ethical as aesthetic is the damage brought about to the principles of the sport by these actions.
The possibility of new types of life on Earth, or elsewhere, is raised by an arsenic-tolerant microbe.
A strange bacteria that can use arsenic as one of its nutrients has been discovered, widening the scope for finding new forms of life on Earth and possibly beyond.
The unusual bacteria discovered by researchers here on Earth, they say, suggests that life could have possibilities beyond the major elements previously considered essential.
Dual capability is possessed by this organism.
Either phosphorus or arsenic can support its growth.

Paul C. W. Davies of Arizona State University, a co-author of the report appearing in Thursday's online edition of the journal Science, commented, 'That makes it very peculiar, though it falls short of being some form of truly `alien' life.'
Life has long been considered to depend on six major elements - carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus, and sulfur.
The bacteria, discovered in Mono Lake, Calif., was found by the researchers to be able to continue growing after phosphorus is substituted with arsenic.
Ariel D. Anbar, a co-author of the report from Arizona State University, said, 'It makes you wonder what else is possible.'
Because researchers need to be able to recognize life, to know what it looks like, the find is important in the search for life beyond Earth, Anbar said.
A microbe found on Earth is the focus of the study.

However, widespread speculation on the Internet was generated by the announcement of a news conference to discuss it, which did not disclose details of the find, speculating that the report would reveal the discovery of extraterrestrial life.
Did it not?

That in other planetary environments organisms might be able to use other elements to drive biochemistry, and that the 'standard' set of elements considered essential for life might not be so fixed, is shown by the discovery, commented Charles Cockell, professor at the Planetary and Space Sciences Research Institute of Open University in Milton Keynes, United Kingdom.
The research team did not include Cockell.
Because this work demonstrates the substitution of one element for another in fundamental biochemistry and the structure of biochemistry, it is considered novel, added Cockell.
A chance discovery it was not.
Mono Lake was targeted by Felisa Wolfe-Simon of NASA's Astrobiology Institute, who led the study, because it has high arsenic levels.
She speculated that a microbe exposed to both arsenic and phosphorus might be able to substitute one for the other, given their chemical similarity.
Mainly because its chemical behavior is so similar to that of phosphorus, arsenic is toxic.
These elements are hard for organisms to tell apart as a result.
But phosphorus works much better than arsenic, which, when it gets in there, tends to gum up the works of our biochemical machinery, explained Anbar.
The bacteria known as GFAJ-1 was collected by the researchers and exposed to increasing concentrations of arsenic, to which it adapted and grew.

That a microbe can live with arsenic instead of phosphorus raises the possibility that a life form using arsenic could occur naturally, either elsewhere on Earth or on another planet or moon where arsenic is more common, although it does grow better on phosphorus.

The idea that arsenic could be substituted for phosphorus isn't new, Jamie S. Foster, an assistant professor of microbiology at the University of Florida, said, but there has never been an example shown to work.
More common in the early times on Earth was Arsenic, she said, which has led researchers to speculate that early life forms might have used it.
NASA supported the research, along with the Department of Energy and the National Institutes of Health.

As the court takes the case, healthcare law challengers dine with Scalia and Thomas.

Behind closed doors, the day found the Supreme Court considering the politically divisive question of whether to hear a challenge to President Obama's healthcare law, while two of its justices, Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, were honored at a dinner thrown by the law firm that is set to argue the case before the high court.
Last Thursday was the occasion when all nine justices gathered for a conference to review the petitions.

A suit brought by 26 states challenging the sweeping healthcare overhaul passed by Congress last year is one of the cases at issue, a law that has been a rallying cry for conservative activists nationwide.

A landmark 5.5-hour argument is expected in March, which the justices have agreed to hear; indeed, the suit's outcome is likely to further roil the 2012 presidential race, which will be in full swing by the time the court's decision is released.
Before the court, Paul Clement, the lawyer, is likely to argue for the law to be thrown out; he served as U.S. solicitor general under George W. Bush's administration.
One of almost two dozen firms that helped sponsor the annual dinner of the Federalist Society, a longstanding group advocating conservative legal principles, was Clement's law firm, Bancroft PLLC.
Jones Day, another firm that sponsored the dinner, represents the National Federation of Independent Business, one of the trade associations that challenged the law.
Pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc, another sponsor, has an enormous financial stake in the outcome of the litigation.
Hours after the court's conference over the case, the dinner was held at a Washington hotel.
Among others, Mitch McConnell, the Senate's top Republican and an avowed opponent of the healthcare law, was in attendance.
Scalia and Thomas were the featured guests at the dinner.
For years, the two justices have been attending events of the Federalist Society.
And it's nothing that ethics rules run afoul of.
In fact, the Code of Conduct that governs the actions of lower federal justices does not apply to justices.

Ethics-in-government activists were alarmed, however, by the close proximity of Scalia and Thomas to two law firms involved in the case, as well as to a company holding a substantial financial interest.

Claims by several justices that the court abides by the same rules as all other federal judges are belied by this stunning breach of ethics and indifference to the code, said Bob Edgar, the president of Common Cause.
At a black-tie fundraiser, the justices were dining and wining with attorneys who have cases pending before the court.
Any claims of impartiality are undercut by their appearance and assistance in fundraising for this event, which is unacceptable.
Little regard have Scalia and Thomas for critics who say they too readily mix the business of the court with agenda-driven groups such as the Federalist Society.
Ginni, the wife of Thomas, is a high-profile conservative activist.
It's Justice Elena Kagan, argue conservatives, who has an ethical issue, not Scalia and Thomas.
When the first legal challenges to the law were brought at the trial court level, Kagan served as solicitor general in the Obama administration.
Kagan has been pushed by her critics to recuse herself from hearing the case, as they say her past investment in defending the law makes her unable to be impartial now.
No indication has been given by Kagan that she will do so.

Is the economy burdened or enhanced by immigration?

Under Nicolas Sarkozy, the immigration policy was subject to criticism from various aspects: a congestion of police, legal, and administrative services due to a policy based on numbers, and its compatibility with the country's self-proclaimed status as the guardian of French human rights.
Rarely is it analyzed from the economic viewpoint.
A lot of consensus between the Left and the Right exists on this subject.

Jacques Chirac set the tone on the Right in 1976 by declaring that `` in a country with 2 million foreign workers, 900,000 unemployed would not become a problem, `` and Michel Rocard on the Left explained in 1990 that `` France cannot accommodate all the world's misery. ``
The degree of generosity, the only difference
The fear of national territory invasion by hordes of Polish plumbers was felt on both the Left and the Right in 2005.
Immigrants are seen as a burden by both sides on the French economy and French society.
In the degree of generosity only resides the difference, which one deigns to grant to immigrants.
François Hollande, in his program, limits himself to banalities, asserts that our immigration problem could be solved through co-development.
An electoral asset it may be, this notion of immigration as a burden and a problem, yet it is economically very costly.

Ian Goldin and Geoffrey Cameron, economists, remind us in their recent book summarizing the latest knowledge on immigration ('Exceptional People: How Migration Shaped Our World and Will Define Our Future,' May 2011, Princeton University Press, 352 pp.) that there is a wide consensus among specialists regarding the positive impact of migration flows on economic growth, wages, and employment in countries admitting immigrants.
Anaemic growth and harmed employment result from restraining immigration.
The notion that immigrants are liable to replace native workers, especially unskilled ones, and exert downward pressure on wages underlies fears about their impact.
In reality, experience demonstrates that immigrants are much more complementary to local labor, rather than replacements, especially in trades where local labor is in shortage.
In sectors not attracting local labor and the most highly skilled ones, unskilled immigrants work where training is not linked to employment offers.
Wages experience a positive effect

As it would be difficult for a surgeon to work in a country with a shortage of anaesthetists, so too do the complementarities between locals and immigrants result in the arrival of immigrants having a positive effect on the pay of locals.
A rise of 1 % in the migratory flow causes an increase of between 0.6 and 0.9 % in real long-term pay, according to calculations by Giovanni Peri.

The fact that immigrants contribute diversity, which is essential for the creation of ideas and economic growth, is often overlooked; a significant proportion of naturalized immigrants are among the American Nobel prize winners, and companies like Google, Intel, Paypal, eBay, and Yahoo were founded by immigrants.
Social systems also benefit from migrants, who contribute an average of 1% to the total budgets of European countries.

It is estimated by the World Labor Organisation that for example in Germany, public budgets will receive an average net contribution of 150,000 Euros from an immigrant arriving at the age of 30, over his lifetime, after subtracting expenditure from receipts.
At the start of his mandate, Nicolas Sarkozy wished to `` look for with the teeth `` missing points of growth.
The opposite effect was precisely achieved by the teeth in question, which were intended to dissuade immigrants.

Alimta is what?
A solution for infusion is made from Alimta, which is a powder, dripped into a vein.
The active substance pemetrexed is contained in it.
For what is Alimta used?
Two types of cancer, including pleural mesothelioma, which is cancer of the lining of the lungs usually caused by exposure to asbestos, are treated with Alimta.

When the cancer is unresectable and malignant, in patients who have not previously received chemotherapy for advanced or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer not affecting squamous cells, Alimta is used in conjunction with cisplatin, another anticancer medicine.
In patients who have not been treated before, Alimta is used in combination with cisplatin, and on its own in those who have received another type of chemotherapy in the past.
Only with a prescription can the medicine be obtained.
Alimta is used how?
Only under the supervision of a doctor qualified in the use of anticancer chemotherapy should Alimta be given.
500 mg of Alimta is the recommended dose per square metre of body surface area, calculated using the patient's height and weight.
Once every three weeks, an intravenous infusion is given, lasting 10 minutes.
A corticosteroid and folic acid (a type of vitamin) should be taken by patients, and vitamin B12 injections received, to reduce side effects during treatment with Alimta.
Before or after the cisplatin dose, an anti-emetic medicine should be given (to prevent vomiting) and fluids (to prevent dehydration), when Alimta is administered with cisplatin.
Patients with abnormal blood counts or certain other side effects should have treatment delayed or discontinued, or a reduction in dose.
Patients with moderate or severe kidney problems should not use Alimta, as it is not recommended.
For more information, the Summary of Product Characteristics (which is also a part of the EPAR) should be seen.
Alimta works how?
Pemetrexed, the active substance in Alimta, is a medicine of the antimetabolite group, which kills dividing cells, such as cancer cells, being a cytotoxic agent.

An active form into which pemetrexed is converted in the body blocks the activity of enzymes involved in producing nucleotides, which are the building blocks of DNA and RNA, the genetic material of cells.
Alimta has been studied how?
Alimta has been studied in one main study involving 456 patients who had not previously received chemotherapy for their malignant pleural mesothelioma treatment.
Compared were the effects of Alimta in combination with cisplatin to those of cisplatin alone.

In one study, the effects of Alimta were compared with those of docetaxel, another anticancer medicine, for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, involving 571 patients who had received chemotherapy in the past and had locally advanced or metastatic disease.

In a study involving 1,725 patients who had not received chemotherapy for lung cancer in the past, Alimta was also compared with gemcitabine, another anticancer medicine, both in combination with cisplatin.
How long the patients survived was the main measure of effectiveness in all three studies.
During the studies, what benefit has Alimta shown?
The survival time of patients with malignant pleural mesothelioma was increased by Alimta.
An average of 12.1 months was the survival for patients receiving Alimta and cisplatin, compared to 9.3 months for those receiving cisplatin alone.
In patients who have previously undergone chemotherapy, the survival time average was 8.3 months when treated with Alimta, as opposed to 7.9 months when docetaxel was the treatment.
In both groups, the average survival time was 10.3 months for patients who had not received chemotherapy in the past.
Patients whose cancer was not affecting squamous cells had longer survival times if they received Alimta than if they received the comparator, however, in both studies.
If their cancer was affecting squamous cells, patients, in contrast, had shorter survival times when receiving Alimta.

Cerenia is what?
Maropitant, the active substance, is contained in Cerenia, which is available in the form of a tablet or an injection solution.
A score line on both sides enables the pale-orange tablets to be halved.
The Pfizer logo is marked on one side of each tablet, and on the other side, the letters MPT and the quantity of maropitant are marked.
Cerenia is used for what?
Vomiting is stopped by Cerenia, which means it is an anti-emetic.
To prevent vomiting in dogs, such as that caused by chemotherapy (medicines used for the treatment of cancer, some of which are known to cause vomiting), it is used.

Cerenia can be used in the treatment of vomiting in combination with supportive measures such as other veterinary treatment or a special diet, either as an injection or with tablets following the injection.
Cerenia can be given for up to five days for these purposes.
Cerenia works how?
A neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptor, which is blocked by Cerenia, acts in the central nervous system.
Cerenia has been studied how?
Either in laboratory dogs or in animal patients at veterinary practises in several European countries and in the USA, a large number of studies with Cerenia were carried out.
Cerenia has shown what benefit during the studies?

Cerenia was shown to be more effective than the placebo by the study results: vomiting was less frequently observed in dogs that were administered the medicine compared to those that received a placebo, both for the treatment and prevention of vomiting.
The injection should be started as the initial treatment for a vomiting dog, since animals in such a state might not be able to retain a tablet, potentially throwing it up intact again.
The tablets can be administered by the animal owner to the dog for follow-up treatment.
Also, only in conjunction with other supportive measures or additional veterinary therapies should the treatment of vomiting be undertaken, while addressing the underlying causes.
The risk associated with Cerenia is what?

When administered daily, Cerenia was generally well tolerated at dosages up to 5 times the recommended doses for an extended period of time, reaching up to 3 times the recommended maximum duration of treatment.
The person who gives the medicine or comes into contact with the animal should take what precautions?
People are not at a particular risk from Cerenia.
